title: Direct Imaging of Atom-by-Atom Structures and Transformations in 2D Moirés
content: Moiré superlattices arising from twisted two-dimensional (2D) materials offer a platform for investigating emergent quantum phenomena such as unconventional superconductivity [1], strongly correlated states [2, 3], and quantum anomalous Hall effect [4]. The interfacial alignment (e.g., twist angle, translation, and lattice mismatch between adjacent layers) is a critical degree of freedom for modulating moiré properties. Although global alignment can be tuned through various fabrication techniques [5–8], achieving precise control of local structures remains challenging due to the heterogenous nature of 2D multilayers [9]. In addition, 2D moirés are highly susceptible to reconfiguration [10, 11]. Understanding the atomic-scale mechanisms governing the structural evolution of 2D moiré is crucial for achieving reliable property measurements and designing of these quantum systems.
